The British Information Commissioners Office, which enforces data-protection laws, filed its initial results of the investigation into the Cambridge Analytica scandal, and accused the tech titan of failing to prevent user data ending up in Cambridge's hands.

"As we have said before, we should have done more to investigate claims about Cambridge Analytica and take action in 2015," Facebook chief privacy officer Erin Egan said in a statement, adding that the company would "respond soon."
Facebook Inc. FB, -1.58% could be slapped with a 500,000-pound fine, or about $660,000, by a U.K. regulator over improperly handled data from 87 million users, the company confirmed late Tuesday.
Facebook can respond to the ICO findings prior to the independent agency reaching its final decision about whether to levy the fine.
The fine represents the profits from roughly 13 minutes of Facebook operations, according to MarketWatch calculations.
Facebook stock was down 1% in after-hours trading and closed down 0.6% to $203.54 during the regular session.
Facebook stock is up 15% this year, as the S&P 500 index SPX, -2.33% has gained 4.5%.
